cards.q: Why are we unable to see objects in a dark room?
cards.a: Because no light is available to reflect from objects into our eyes.

cards.q: What makes objects visible during the day?
cards.a: Sunlight reflects from objects and enters our eyes, making them visible.

cards.q: What role does a transparent medium play in visibility?
cards.a: It transmits light through it, allowing us to see objects placed behind.

cards.q: List some everyday optical phenomena associated with light.
cards.a: Image formation by mirrors, twinkling of stars, rainbow colors, bending of light, sharp shadows.

cards.q: What evidence shows that light travels in straight lines?
cards.a: A small source of light casts a sharp shadow of an opaque object, indicating straight-line propagation.
Diffraction is the bending of light around small obstacles, where the straight-line ray model fails.

cards.q: What does wave theory of light explain?
cards.a: It explains phenomena like diffraction and interference of light.

cards.q: Why was particle theory of light introduced?
cards.a: Because wave theory was inadequate to explain lightâ€“matter interactions, so light was considered as particles.

cards.q: What is the modern quantum theory of light?
cards.a: It reconciles wave and particle properties, showing light is neither purely a wave nor purely a particle.

cards.q: What are the main topics studied in this chapter?
cards.a: Reflection of light by spherical mirrors and refraction of light, with real-life applications.
